commit_list.message:
Various improvements to the tutorial and building experience.

- Improve geo ip download stability
- Retry default geo ip download if corrupt
- Clarify docs on building & where to get artifact

Update docs and examples for log4j2 usage.

- Put configs early in classpath in examples so log4j2.xml will get picked up properly
- Add an example log4j2.xml file.
- Update Logging doc.

Add common config dir to classpath in examples

Also adds query examples in the Cluster tutorial

Working toward making it easier to add new SegmentPullers.

1) Move the local cacheFile logic out of the S3 pullers into the SingleSegmentLoader
2) Make the S3SegmentPuller just pull down the file
3) Make the Loader do the unzip, ungzip, or rename
4) 2 and 3 make S3ZippedSegmentPuller not necessary (still there, just deprecated and empty)
4) Tweak the TaskToolbox so that the Pullers returned by getSegmentGetters behave the same as they did before
ignore intellij and generated files
removed managed plugins/project folder
Removed need to reverse sort the logs in memory.  Switched to using the --reverse flag on the git log call
Git log now fills in the full commit message.
Pulled out a LogFormatBuilder for git.

Finally figured out a way to test that gitprojects were calling update against
the correct repo directory on updateLogs calls.

Added tearDowns to cleanup metaClass code.

Discovered side-effects and fixed'em.  Grails does extra magic
to domain classes that it doesn't do for non domain classes.
so when mocking methods on non-domain classes its a bit of
a hassle to use the metaClass.  may be better/simpler to
use the mocking stuff.

Added support for Analyzers.  AKA Monkeys.

Now when an updateLogs action happens, the top level analyzerService
(AnalyzerMonkeys at the moment) will be told to analyze the project
if it has  any new commits.  The service uses AnalyzerBookmarks
to keep track of where an analyzer last analyzed a project (which
commit id it analyzed last).  The service grabs all the commit
logs that the analyzer hasn't seen and feeds them to it one
commit at a time.
Rebase and clarify where the generted key is

Merge pull request #25 from orchestrate-io/jde-event-crud

Event Changes
Adding updated events features

Merge pull request #20 from orchestrate-io/jde-list-updates

Add info about beforeKey/endKey as well as search pagination
Add info about beforeKey/endKey as well as search pagination
single
Game Over
Counted and displayed score
Created and displayed game over
got ball bouncing
bouce ball off edges
got ball moving
set interval for game loop
Got bat moving
added bat and ball png's
Initial game work.
Upped to Druid 0.2.7.  Fixed issues with aws/s3 settings.

3) Make the Loader do the unzip, ungzip, or rename

4) Tweak the TaskToolbox so that the Pullers returned by getSegmentGetters behave the same as they did before

Working toward making it easier to add new SegmentPullers.

1) Move the local cacheFile logic out of the S3 pullers into the SingleSegmentLoader
2) Make the S3SegmentPuller just pull down the file
3) Make the Loader do the unzip, ungzip, or rename
4) 2 and 3 make S3ZippedSegmentPuller not necessary (still there, just deprecated and empty)
4) Tweak the TaskToolbox so that the Pullers returned by getSegmentGetters behave the same as they did before
UPdated to grails 1.3.3
Its been a long time since a commit.  Not even sure what is in this.
Added ability to add transaction.  Not all the way there...won't calc balances for it.
On first page load, only show the full day of the last reconciled tx and limit to 20 records.  Need to figure out when/how to handle tx that take awhile to clear.
Minor tweaks
Connected to real data.  In 'test' mode, the app uses a mysql database connection to pull tx info
updated grails.

Bunch more changes.  Simplified down to just one "Env".  Now calling the module container
simply 'env'.  env support a simple observer pattern.  Only event atm is domready.  Put in
jquery as an implementor that can support/fire the domready event.  when 'using', the callback
will (by default) be called after domready.  Pulled out a Resolver notion.  The LocalResolver
will only resolve based on what is in the env container.  Eventually will have a RemoteResolver
that will have all the path-to-file smarts.  Oh, and calling the underlying library "shade"
now.
Added some tweaks to get the Login demo working with the newer approach.  Also added support for the Modules:Page meta tag.  Really need a dom ready implementation soon.
some clean up.  dropped Modules.js.  May eventually be a generated file that combines BootModule.js and ModuleContainer.js
simplified some more.  back to just 2 ModuleContainers:  BootModule and ModuleContainer.

lots of moving around.  bootloader process is now 3 objects deep.  The super-simple initial Modules instance, then the one that delays until a for-real ModuleContainer is available and then the ModuleContainer.  The upside is that all but the first super-simple one can have dependencies loaded.
Started to trim down oasis.ModuleContainer
More moving around.

More refinement.  Came up with the notion of a util module/closure within the module config
hash.  This allows util methods to have a different scope when those utils may be creating
and returning closures and the base module scope may be a bit hairy.  Its also nice to
have a place to look for utils.  Haven't quite decided it any automagic-ness will happen
with them yet.  It may be auto-thunked by the base module on add.

more moving around.  settling in on responsibilities.  Modules is responsible for finding a suitable container.  ModuleContainer is one such Container.  It has been a bit confusing, but i think i like where it is headed now.  I think
Lots of spiking.  This commit has the results.  Mostly a tweaked module pattern.  Some files are still just 'thoughts'
Got the container back to centered in ie...didn't think i needed to pull the text-align center trick anymore...ugh
round 2 of l&f of the grid.  made the look consistent across browsers.  really sux i cant use colgroups for border in ie6,7
First stab at "dream" transaction/burn table.
Fixed issue with letMeIn using save instead of merge.  Will need to move to services I suppose.
Added BASIC registration
Locked down the User and UserBrowserControllers to require login and appropriate access.  Evenually we'll do something more sophisticated.
tweaked the label on the grid page
Moved the body div up into the main layout

moved the developer panel into the layout and added a flag to
user that indicates the user is a dev.  tweaked the list
styling a bit.
moved logout link into main layout for logged in users

move the 'is user setup' condition check into the controller and
out of the gsp.

Modified the unimplemented accountList page to display as an error and provide
the 'let me in' button.

Cleaned up the styling and markup structure.  Separated grails styles/layout
from the apps.

Now there is a grails layout that all the scaffolded stuff will use, and
the rest of the app will use the main layout.
forgot to save the user
added a bit of a tutorial option for initial logins
Forgot to add directories to git prior to commit/push
added a user home action and a logout action
Added User and UserController as well as some login logic.  An admin user is created on startup and there is a UserBrowser to use for now.  Still no real security checks
Added login form
Initial commit.
Adds the RsCrashTest
Adds readme
nuke other test
Initial empty scan results test.

commit_list.message: Upped to Druid 0.2.7.  Fixed issues with aws/s3 settings.
Move instructions to wiki
Switch back to the logging emitter
Druid test/eval harness

Fixed issues with Cardinality pull request

- SpecTest was calling a method that didn't exist
- Conjurer was defaulting to 'customSchema' so non-cardinality examples were failing
- The template parsing for the json form was building the template (in the 'if'), but
  then overwriting it with the non-json template parser (no 'else').

Got those fixed, plan is to add tests for those and then start to work on
refactoring it around so that nodes generate values vs strings and
the stringification moves to become a 'printer' concern.

Also adds query examples in the Cluster tutorial

Working toward making it easier to add new SegmentPullers.

1) Move the local cacheFile logic out of the S3 pullers into the SingleSegmentLoader
2) Make the S3SegmentPuller just pull down the file
3) Make the Loader do the unzip, ungzip, or rename
4) 2 and 3 make S3ZippedSegmentPuller not necessary (still there, just deprecated and empty)
4) Tweak the TaskToolbox so that the Pullers returned by getSegmentGetters behave the same as they did before
Added note about changing custom serializer support.

Moved a few more settings to the serializer interface.  Getting closer to seeing how I want
to pull the settings out into its own object.  Will wait until all are pulled up first.
added to todo
Made min decimal setting configurable via the serializer interface.  still thinking about how best to do the feature tweaking.

Made support for global decimal precision configurable.  By default, Float, Double, BigDecimal are
output with String.valueOf directly (using the new RawNumberAppender).  When precision is configured,
then it switches to the PreciseNumberFormatter using specified maxDecimalDigits (no support for min
yet).  Need to detect setting it to < 0 to switch back to the RawNumberAppender).
refactored numberformatter in prep for making decimal precision configurable
Made non-ascii escaping optional and not the default.  Still trying to find an approach to 'features' I like, meanwhile, the interface for JsonSerializers gets messier
Added some settings files to try to put some names to the differences between serializer impls
Switched to rendering dates/calendars as timestamps.  Want to eventually add option for rendering as ISO string
Made escaping forward slash optional and off by default.  Don't like where it is atm, still getting a feel for how enabling/tweaking 'features' should work
updated todo
Added NOT_SERIALIZABLE filter to ignore/skip non-serializable property values
Added an abstract serializer to implement the String serialize(Object) method.  May want to yank this back out and just have a utility or something to do this.
Added xstream for comparison.  It is 10x slower than jsondumper. It does seem to have some form of cycle detection and json referencing
Added jackson tests for comparison.  It is SMOKIN fast!  The walker does have a cleaner design though, and has some features not in Jackson (cycle detection)
Added to todo
Added todo to keep track of stuff.
Added license info to the pom

Added Apache 2.0 license.  Not sure if i'll be adding the header to all the sources or
finding a way to script it (perhaps as part of bundling the source archive?)
Switched to org.merecode packages from com.itsalleasy.
Added mockito dependency in prep for simplifying the tests using stubs
Switched the WalkerTest to be testng
ignored the .project and .classpath files
Switched to using testng.
Switched to using maven.
More refactoring and renaming for clarity.
Renamed filter method to matches and renamed param to ignoreFilter to be more clear about what the filter does

Tweaked the accessor detection strategy again.  Now no accessors with Class<?> return types will be walked.  May pull this out into a sort of return type filter to globally ignore certain packages or classes
tightened up the logic that finds bean accessors
Renamed some of the WalkerVisitor interface methods to be more clear

Started refactoring the BasicNodeWalker.  Looks like the NodeWalkerFactory isn't
what should be exposed...feels more like an IteratorTransformer (or something)
wants to come out.  The transform would be responsible for taking an object and
creating an Iterable from it.  IF that Iterable is a NameValuePairs, then
it will be treated as bean properties, otherwise it'll be treated as
array elements.
Exposed NodeWalkerFactory all the way up to JsonDumper so it can be injected.

Got the NodeWalkers going.  I'd do more, but I'm tired.

Next steps would be to pull the NodeWalkerFactories out into their own
top level classes (IterableNodeWalkerFactory, etc), then expose it up to
the JsonDumper level so we can plug in custom NodeWalkers.

May wind up getting rid of the whole AppenderRegistry stuff.  Now that
it has been split from the node walking, it seems there isn't as
much value there.  As long as perf doesn't drop, but I guess the other
consideration is how frequent custom appenders would be.

Simplified jsondumper.  Back to allowing an AppenderRegistry to be plugged in.  Starting
to grow out a NodeWalker.  Didn't intend to check it in...it was a refactoring that i'd
reverted, but the new files stuck around.  I'm ok w/it b/c I'm looking at that now and
will be either putting them to use or nuking shortly.

Added a speed test for a dumper with no reference tracking.  Comes in at 11ms and almost no memory footprint.
Also pulled out a JsonWalkerAppenderRegistry and made BasicInheritanceRegistry have no default appenders.
Added JsonIOException as a first stab at not ignoring the IOExceptions.

Still struggling with Appender/Serializer seeming too similar.  Made sure JsonDumper was stateless.
Don't close the writer (we didn't create it).

Need to get a Walk runtime exception so that we stop ignoring the IOExceptions that we may catch.

More minor renaming.  Nuked ObjectRefAppender.  Not needed.

Now for some Walker refactoring.
More renaming.
Renamed JsonSerializer to just Appender and moved a bunch of things around.
Removed all now-moot Serializers.  Next to rename them.  Appenders?

Nuked the JsonWriter and all interface methods referencing it.  Showed some interesting
things, like the Collection and NVPair Serializers don't do anything in the new walker
approach.

Will focus on getting the json visitor side of things straightened out for now, then
move on to continuing with the walker refactoring.  The walker may wind up having a similar
registry notion for looking up the right strategry based on type.  OR it might just do
an adapter/translator registry to create the right kind of iterable for the more complex
types:  either an NVPairs iterable for beans, or a straight object iterable for collections.

Moved tests around.  Added serializer and speed tests for NetSfJson, JsonDumper, and JsonWalkerSerializer.  Yeah,
some name changes will need to be made.  The NetSfJsonSerializerTests are actually failing.  I'm not sure if it
is due to some false assumptions of the test (eg i'm not sure dump("foo") should *really* output "foo" without
a wrapping json object), or just something netsf doesn't expect to handle.

Still need to prune the old code line.
Rearranged some params.  Minor cleanup.

Tweaked the JsonSerializerTest to focus squarly on performance. Added memory
printouts (need to move them to asserts or an average calc).  Added net.sf.json
and a test for it for comparison.

So at the end of the day, performance looks ok.  I do need to split the perf tests into
their own fixture so I can un-comment the other tests.

Our worst case was using the "WithPath" Policy and it came in at
18ms and 975KB (burst) memory usage.
net.sf.json came it at
150ms and 1470KB (burst) memory usage (just for the JSON object anyway).
Our best case was the "Do Nothing" TrackingPolicy and it came in at:
11.5ms and 521KB (burst) memory usage.

Bunch of cleanup still to do, but at least is is on track perf-wise and I feel
OK to drop the other code line.
removed unused item param from (push/pop)Path methods
added the constructor for the tracking policy

Added a TrackingPolicy concept/interface.

Determined that the tracking of circular references is actually quite significant
on performance, especially when remembering the paths (more memory intensive). So,
there are 3 TrackingPolicy implementations:
TrackingPolicyThatRemembersObjectsAndPaths : Does what we were doing before, remembers
	objects it has already seen, and will indicate it has seen it, and provide the
	remembered path when asked (the Walker is still responsible for asking the policy
	for this information and passing it to a revisit method on the WalkerVisitor).
	This one takes about 70ms to serialize the 5000 beans (194ish KB of json).
TrackingPolicyThatRemembersObjects : This one tracks the objects, but doesn't remember
	the paths.  You'd use this one if you had circ refs, but didn't care about the
	traversal path to get back to the first path the object was seen at.
	This one takes about 60ms to serialize the 5000 beans (and this one may turn out
	to be the default...just wondering if we should have 2 revisit methods, one
	that takes the path and one that doesnt, so WalkerVisitors don't have to check
	for nulls).
TrackingPolicyThatDoesNotTrackAnything : This one does not support circular graphs.
	You'd use is when you are sure you aren't going to need this support and want
	the added speedup for that goodness.
	This one takes 20ms (!!!) to serialize the 5000 beans.  S..i..c..k..!!!

Man what a mess.  My excuse will be that sometimes things have to get worse
to get better :)

In this case, I felt like the dumper/Writer was doing too much.  It was
doing object/bean traversal and serialization.  This commit explored
actually pulling out the traversal concern into a Walker.  SO,
the Walker is responsible for knowing how to walk over an object
graph, and it takes a WalkerVisitor which has various callback
methods on it to be called during object traversal (very SAX-y).
Then, there is a JsonProcessor (implements WalkerVisitor...will
rename to something better later) that handles the actual JSON
specific serialization logic.

I didn't want to drastically break what was there, so the Writer
was largely left alone, except to add a parallel toJson method that
took an actual Writer (as opposed to the existing one that took
a JsonWriter) which was a quick copy-paste for the most part of the
other method (remember I did say it was ugly :)).  I wanted to get
to a quick Proof of Concept before really ripping out the guts
and wanted to be able to run the tests against both approaches as
I went.  In the end the Walker approach is about 13-15% faster than
the original Writer approach....and it has the concerns split out.

I considered not checking this in yet (it even has a failing test
on the Json stuff b/c it doesn't handle circular refs yet), but
decided it needed to go in...then I can start really ripping things
apart.  I suppose i could create a branch, but...ah well.
Various cleanup.  Getting closer to pulling out a sort-of Object Graph Walker...to split the graph walking concerns out of the writer.

Pulled "shouldNot..." method out into a filter interface and added an instance for each if check.
Actually bumped the performance up by about 10%.  win.

trimming up the public api.  makes it easier to see what bits need to be pulled out of Writer.  Looking specifically at a Filter first (to pull out the shouldFilterOut method) and then on to an eventing/sax-type visitor object (to handle the begin/end type methods.
added nullcheck and accessor for the builder
Switched to using a StringBuilderWriter (custom) for improved straight string dumping
Switched to a LinkedHash for performance in the registry
minor cleanup
further simplified the circ ref check and the ObjectRefSerializer
Use IdentityHashMap for cache of objects already written.  This way equality (.equals) will not flag a ref as written
Removed ReferencableSerializer and found a better approach to the Cir Refs
removed unnecessary if
missed a file add
Merge branch 'master' of git@github.com:housejester/jsondumper
Added convenience defaulting for the registry in both the Dumper and the Writer
Pulled out the circular ref logic from Writer into its own registry. Not sure it fits there, feels a bit to exposed, perhaps better as an inner class.  Want to see how this goes for a bit
Modified NullLiteralSerializer to delegate to a (new) appendNullLiteral method on the Writer.  Not sure why, but it felt more appropriate.

Refactored SerializerRegistry to remove the register method and have the lookup method
lookup by (ie take) the Object instead of the Object class.  Also added a few optimizations.

Cleaned up a few serializers and fixed BasicSerializer to add the default
serializers unconditionally (used to only be added when using the no args
constructor).

Modified JsonWriter to take the root object on write instead of
on constructor.
Moved some responsibilities around.  Now have begin/end object/array methods.  Probably looks a bit uglier atm but working toward having a context stack in the writer.

Added support for unicode.  Now will output all ascii printable characters
and the unicode escape sequence otherwise (spec says any unicode character
which should allow any char from java, but we'll do this for now).

Also removed dependency on commonslang for their stringescapeutils.  it
wasn't escaping per JSON spec anyhow.
First actual code commit.  Should have done this earlier.
first commit

Working toward making it easier to add new SegmentPullers.

1) Move the local cacheFile logic out of the S3 pullers into the SingleSegmentLoader
2) Make the S3SegmentPuller just pull down the file
3) Make the Loader do the unzip, ungzip, or rename
4) 2 and 3 make S3ZippedSegmentPuller not necessary (still there, just deprecated and empty)
4) Tweak the TaskToolbox so that the Pullers returned by getSegmentGetters behave the same as they did before

commit_list.repo_description: Apache Druid (Incubating) - Column oriented distributed data store ideal for powering interactive applications

commit_list.message:
Various improvements to the tutorial and building experience.

- Improve geo ip download stability
- Retry default geo ip download if corrupt
- Clarify docs on building & where to get artifact

Update docs and examples for log4j2 usage.

- Put configs early in classpath in examples so log4j2.xml will get picked up properly
- Add an example log4j2.xml file.
- Update Logging doc.

Add common config dir to classpath in examples

Also adds query examples in the Cluster tutorial

Working toward making it easier to add new SegmentPullers.

1) Move the local cacheFile logic out of the S3 pullers into the SingleSegmentLoader
2) Make the S3SegmentPuller just pull down the file
3) Make the Loader do the unzip, ungzip, or rename
4) 2 and 3 make S3ZippedSegmentPuller not necessary (still there, just deprecated and empty)
4) Tweak the TaskToolbox so that the Pullers returned by getSegmentGetters behave the same as they did before
